feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued May 6 at 3:07PM CDT until May 6 at 6:15PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
FFWHGX
The National Weather Service in League City has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Central Brazos County in southeastern Texas... Central Burleson County in southeastern Texas...
* Until 615 PM CDT.
* At 307 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 to 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... College Station, Bryan, Caldwell, Kurten, Wixon Valley and Kyle Field.
This includes the following streams and drainages... Sand Creek, Still Creek, Hopes Creek, Little Brazos River, Little Cedar Creek, Bee Creek, Reed Creek, Elm Branch, Berry Creek, Smith Branch, Burton Creek, Brushy Creek, Wickson Creek, Carrington Creek, Rocky Creek, Cottonwood Branch, Cedar Creek, Red Slough, Old River, Pecan Branch, Jim Branch, Brazos River, Damn Branch, Carters Creek, Copper Creek, Thompsons Creek, Lewis Creek, Turkey Creek, Cobb Branch, Allcorn Creek, Pecan Hollow Creek, Davidson Creek, Robertson Branch, Navasota River, Little Wickson Creek, White Creek and Jack Creek.

cap:parameter.value: NWS: TORNADO WARNING in this area til 4:30 PM EDT. Take shelter now. Check media.

National Weather Service: TORNADO WARNING in this area until 4:30 PM EDT. Take shelter now in a basement or an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy building. If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and protect yourself from flying debris. Check media.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued May 6 at 2:56PM CDT until May 8 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Lake Charles LA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of Louisiana, including the following parishes, Allen, Avoyelles, Beauregard, East Cameron, Evangeline, Lafayette, Lower Iberia, Lower St. Martin, Lower St. Mary, Lower Vermilion, Northern Acadia, Northern Calcasieu, Northern Jefferson Davis, Rapides, Southern Acadia, Southern Calcasieu, Southern Jefferson Davis, St. Landry, Upper Iberia, Upper St. Martin, Upper St. Mary, Upper Vermilion, Vernon and West Cameron and southeast Texas, including the following areas, Hardin, Lower Jefferson, Northern Jasper, Northern Newton, Northern Orange, Southern Jasper, Southern Newton, Southern Orange, Tyler and Upper Jefferson.
* WHEN...Through Thursday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Extensive street flooding and flooding of creeks and rivers are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - 4 to 8 inches of rainfall is expected with some areas possibly seeing up to 10 to 12 inches. River responses could be significant in the Lower Neches, Sabine, Lower Calcasieu, Mermentau, and Vermilion basins. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Watch issued May 6 at 11:55AM AKDT until May 7 at 12:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by an ice jam continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Yukon River at Ft. Yukon
* WHEN...Through Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Low-water crossings may be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - The breakup front has jammed on the downstream side of Six Mile Island. It is causing water to rise in Fort Yukon. Low lying areas including some roads and the boat launch are covered by water
- Upstream gages and reports do not indicate a significant surge of water coming from upstream. So while water levels may rise slightly higher, significant flooding is not expected at this time.
- Residents should continue to monitor this situation closely until the jam has released as water levels could change quickly. The River Watch Team will continue to fly the area today and provide updates as available
- Http://www.weather.gov/aprfc
- If you live near or along the Yukon River stay alert and be prepared to take action.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued May 6 at 9:52AM MDT by NWS Pueblo CO
entry.summary:
ESFPUB
Widespread rainfall of 2 inches or more over the next 24 hours will result in rises for area rivers and streams through the remainder of the week.
Flooding is anticipated for locations along the Arkansas River, between Pueblo and La Junta, and for the Purgatoire River near Las Animas. Flooding for these locations is anticipated to begin in the morning hours on Wednesday, May 7.
While flooding is not anticipated for other streams at this time, rises and hazardous flow conditions can still be expected for Fountain Creek, St. Charles River, Huerfano River, Cucharas River, Apishapa River and other area streams, in addition to other locations along the Arkansas River and Purgatoire River.
Swift flowing water and unstable stream banks pose a hazard for those near area streams. Heed any directives and orders from law enforcement and local emergency management, and never attempt to drive over flooded roadways!
entry.cap:areaDesc: Baca, CO; Bent, CO; Crowley, CO; Custer, CO; El Paso, CO; Fremont, CO; Huerfano, CO; Kiowa, CO; Las Animas, CO; Otero, CO; Prowers, CO; Pueblo, CO
